required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Pharmacokinetic Study of Milrinone in Babies With Persistent Pulmonary Hypertension of the Newborn
clinical_study.official_title: Milrinone Pharmacokinetics and Pharmacodynamics in Newborns With Persistent Pulmonary Hypertension of the Newborn - a Pilot Study to Enable a Randomized Trial of Intervention

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this pilot study is to determine a safe dose of milrinone to use in a larger study of babies with persistent pulmonary hypertension of the newborn (PPHN).

detailed_description.textblock:
Persistent pulmonary hypertension of the newborn (PPHN) is a condition in which the pulmonary vasculature fails to relax after birth resulting in severe hypoxemia. This condition has a high rate of mortality and morbidity. The current standard of care is treatment with inhaled nitric oxide (iNO). However, for many babies this treatment does not provide sufficient improvement in oxygenation.
In this study, subjects already receiving nitric oxide will be randomized to one of two dosing regimens of milrinone. They will receive milrinone IV for 24 hours and will be monitored for 24 hours afterwards. During this time, milrinone assays will be performed by blood sampling. Echocardiograms will also be performed to explore the pharmacodynamics of milrinone. Safety monitoring will be performed.

primary_outcome.measure: Define Plasma Concentration-time Profile of Milrinone in Neonates With Persistent Pulmonary Hypertension of the Newborn (PPHN) - Clearance (CL, mL/Min)
primary_outcome.time_frame: End of bolus dose, 15 minutes prior to end of infusion (EOI), at four time points after EOI with final sample at 12-15 hours after EOI (timing based on infant's weight)
primary_outcome.description: The schedule of milrinone pharmacokinetic (PK) sampling varied by weight to minimize blood sampling. For babies weighing less than 3kg, samples were drawn at the end of the bolus, 15 minutes prior to the end of infusion (EOI) and 20 minutes, 1, 2, 6 and 12 hours after EOI. For babies weighing 3kg or more, samples were drawn at the end of the bolus, 6 hours after start of infusion, 15 minutes prior to the EOI and 30 minutes, 1, 3, 9 and 15 hours after EOI. Milrinone plasma concentrations were determined using a validated high-performance mass spectrometry assay.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in Oxygenation Index (OI) From Baseline to up to 24 Hours After Start of Milrinone Infusion
secondary_outcome.time_frame: for up to 24 hours after start of infusion
secondary_outcome.description: Oxygenation Index (mean airway pressure*Fraction of Inspired Oxygen/Partial Pressure of Oxygen in the blood) was calculated at baseline and every 6 hours after start of infusion until 12-24 hours after initiation of milrinone infusion.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in Myocardial Performance Index (MPI) From Baseline to up to 24 Hours After Start of Milrinone Infusion
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Up to 24 hours after start of infusion
secondary_outcome.description: An echocardiogram obtained while on milrinone was obtained with the goal of attempting to look for improvements in parameters associated with pulmonary hypertension. The primary parameter measured was the myocardial performance index (MPI). An Echocardiogram was performed at baseline (pre-infusion) and repeated 12-24 hours ater the initiation of the Milrinone infusion. Also known as the Tei index, the MPI is an index that incorporates both systolic and diastolic time intervals in expressing global systolic and diastolic ventricular function. Systolic dysfunction prolongs preejection (isovolumic contraction time, IVCT) and a shortening of the ejection time (ET). Both systolic and diastolic dysfunction result in abnormality in myocardial relaxation which prolongs the relaxation period (isovolumic relaxation time, IVRT). Normal value for MPI is 0.39+/-0.05 with dilated cardiomyopathy value of MPI at 0.59+/-0.10 (both units on a scale)

arm_group.description: Subjects will receive a bolus intravenous (IV) infusion of 50 mcg/kg/min of milrinone lactate over 1 hour followed by a continuous IV infusion of 0.5 mcg/kg/min milrinone lactate over 24 hours. After completion of infusion, subjects will be monitored for an additional 24 hours.

Subjects will receive a bolus intravenous (IV) infusion of 20 mcg/kg/min of milrinone lactate over 1 hour followed by a continuous IV infusion of 0.2 mcg/kg/min milrinone lactate over 24 hours. After completion of infusion, subjects will be monitored for an additional 24 hours.

intervention.description: Milrinone lactate will be given first as an IV bolus over one hour at the assigned dose level, followed by a 24 hour IV infusion at the assigned dose level.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Gestational age > 34 weeks
- Post-natal age < 10 days
- Hypoxemia defined by: Oxygenation Index (OI) >15 (Mean Airway Pressure x Fraction of Inspired Oxygen (FiO2) x 100 /PaO2) as drawn from two post-ductal arterial blood gas samples (in-dwelling arterial catheter) taken at least 15 minutes apart. OR mechanically ventilated and with >75% FiO2 for >6 hours while on iNO
- Absence of congenital heart disease based on a two-dimensional echocardiogram and/or clinical assessment
- An in-dwelling arterial catheter to facilitate painless sampling
- Currently on iNO or plan to start iNO before enrollment
Exclusion Criteria:
- Lethal non-cardiac congenital anomalies including diaphragmatic hernia
- Clinically apparent bleeding; thrombocytopenia <30,000 or other laboratory evidence of coagulopathy
- Currently on extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO)or plan to initiate ECMO within 2 hours of enrollment

facility.name: Children's Hospital of Michigan/Hutzel Women's Hospital

participant_flow.recruitment_details: Recruitment began in June 2010 at three large academic medical centers. The study was closed to enrollment at all sites in November 2013.

group.title: High Dose Milrinone
group.description: Subjects received a 50 mcg/kg loading dose of milrinone lactate given intravenously (IV) over 1 hour followed by an IV infusion of 0.5 mcg/kg/min over 24 hours.

group.title: Low Dose Milrinone
group.description: Subjects received a 20 mcg/kg loading dose of milrinone lactate given intravenously (IV) over 1 hour followed by an IV infusion of 0.2 mcg/kg/min over 24 hours.

group.title: High Dose Milrinone
group.description: Subjects received a 50mcg/kg loading dose of milrinone lactate given intravenously (IV) over 1 hour followed by an IV infusion of 0.5mcg/kg over 24 hours

group.title: Low Dose Milrinone
group.description: Subjects received a 20mcg/kg loading dose of milrinone lactate given intravenously (IV) over 1 hour followed by an IV infusion of 0.2mcg/kg over 24 hours

class.title: Native Hawaiian or Other Pacific Islander

outcome.title: Change in Oxygenation Index (OI) From Baseline to up to 24 Hours After Start of Milrinone Infusion
outcome.description: Oxygenation Index (mean airway pressure*Fraction of Inspired Oxygen/Partial Pressure of Oxygen in the blood) was calculated at baseline and every 6 hours after start of infusion until 12-24 hours after initiation of milrinone infusion.
outcome.time_frame: for up to 24 hours after start of infusion
outcome.population: OI was calculated every 6 hours after start of infusion for 24 hours.

group.title: High Dose Milrinone
group.description: 7 subjects were enrolled into this arm, of these only 4 completed study treatment.

group.title: Low Dose Milrinone
group.description: 5 subjects were enrolled into this arm, of these only 2 completed study treatment.

measure.title: Change in Oxygenation Index (OI) From Baseline to up to 24 Hours After Start of Milrinone Infusion
measure.description: Oxygenation Index (mean airway pressure*Fraction of Inspired Oxygen/Partial Pressure of Oxygen in the blood) was calculated at baseline and every 6 hours after start of infusion until 12-24 hours after initiation of milrinone infusion.
measure.population: OI was calculated every 6 hours after start of infusion for 24 hours.

outcome.title: Define Plasma Concentration-time Profile of Milrinone in Neonates With Persistent Pulmonary Hypertension of the Newborn (PPHN) - Clearance (CL, mL/Min)
outcome.description: The schedule of milrinone pharmacokinetic (PK) sampling varied by weight to minimize blood sampling. For babies weighing less than 3kg, samples were drawn at the end of the bolus, 15 minutes prior to the end of infusion (EOI) and 20 minutes, 1, 2, 6 and 12 hours after EOI. For babies weighing 3kg or more, samples were drawn at the end of the bolus, 6 hours after start of infusion, 15 minutes prior to the EOI and 30 minutes, 1, 3, 9 and 15 hours after EOI. Milrinone plasma concentrations were determined using a validated high-performance mass spectrometry assay.
outcome.time_frame: End of bolus dose, 15 minutes prior to end of infusion (EOI), at four time points after EOI with final sample at 12-15 hours after EOI (timing based on infant's weight)
outcome.population: The pharmacokinetic analysis, including the primary outcome parameter, Clearance, was planned a priori to include all the participants pooled together. A PK analysis by arm wouldn't be appropriate. The randomization arms were only created to explore the secondary clinical and pharmacodynamic outcomes.

group.title: Milrinone Population
group.description: Population model developed based on 6 subjects who completed study treatment and were deemed evaluable.

measure.title: Define Plasma Concentration-time Profile of Milrinone in Neonates With Persistent Pulmonary Hypertension of the Newborn (PPHN) - Clearance (CL, mL/Min)
measure.description: The schedule of milrinone pharmacokinetic (PK) sampling varied by weight to minimize blood sampling. For babies weighing less than 3kg, samples were drawn at the end of the bolus, 15 minutes prior to the end of infusion (EOI) and 20 minutes, 1, 2, 6 and 12 hours after EOI. For babies weighing 3kg or more, samples were drawn at the end of the bolus, 6 hours after start of infusion, 15 minutes prior to the EOI and 30 minutes, 1, 3, 9 and 15 hours after EOI. Milrinone plasma concentrations were determined using a validated high-performance mass spectrometry assay.
measure.population: The pharmacokinetic analysis, including the primary outcome parameter, Clearance, was planned a priori to include all the participants pooled together. A PK analysis by arm wouldn't be appropriate. The randomization arms were only created to explore the secondary clinical and pharmacodynamic outcomes.

outcome.title: Change in Myocardial Performance Index (MPI) From Baseline to up to 24 Hours After Start of Milrinone Infusion
outcome.description: An echocardiogram obtained while on milrinone was obtained with the goal of attempting to look for improvements in parameters associated with pulmonary hypertension. The primary parameter measured was the myocardial performance index (MPI). An Echocardiogram was performed at baseline (pre-infusion) and repeated 12-24 hours ater the initiation of the Milrinone infusion. Also known as the Tei index, the MPI is an index that incorporates both systolic and diastolic time intervals in expressing global systolic and diastolic ventricular function. Systolic dysfunction prolongs preejection (isovolumic contraction time, IVCT) and a shortening of the ejection time (ET). Both systolic and diastolic dysfunction result in abnormality in myocardial relaxation which prolongs the relaxation period (isovolumic relaxation time, IVRT). Normal value for MPI is 0.39+/-0.05 with dilated cardiomyopathy value of MPI at 0.59+/-0.10 (both units on a scale)
outcome.time_frame: Up to 24 hours after start of infusion

group.title: High Dose Milrinone
group.description: 7 subjects were enrolled into the study, of these 4 completed study treatment.

group.title: Low Dose Milrinone
group.description: 5 subjects were enrolled into the study, of these 2 completed study treatment and only 1 received 2 MPI measurements

measure.title: Change in Myocardial Performance Index (MPI) From Baseline to up to 24 Hours After Start of Milrinone Infusion
measure.description: An echocardiogram obtained while on milrinone was obtained with the goal of attempting to look for improvements in parameters associated with pulmonary hypertension. The primary parameter measured was the myocardial performance index (MPI). An Echocardiogram was performed at baseline (pre-infusion) and repeated 12-24 hours ater the initiation of the Milrinone infusion. Also known as the Tei index, the MPI is an index that incorporates both systolic and diastolic time intervals in expressing global systolic and diastolic ventricular function. Systolic dysfunction prolongs preejection (isovolumic contraction time, IVCT) and a shortening of the ejection time (ET). Both systolic and diastolic dysfunction result in abnormality in myocardial relaxation which prolongs the relaxation period (isovolumic relaxation time, IVRT). Normal value for MPI is 0.39+/-0.05 with dilated cardiomyopathy value of MPI at 0.59+/-0.10 (both units on a scale)

reported_events.time_frame: Adverse event assessment was performed continuously from baseline (pre-infusion) through 24 hours after the completion of the milrinone infusion (total of 48 hours).
reported_events.desc: Included vital signs (i.e., blood pressure, measured hourly per standard of care), cardiorespiratory monitoring (ii.e., cardiac rhythm monitored continuously per standard of care), laboratory data (arterial blood gas collected ever 4 hours; hematology and serum chemistry collected every 24 hours), and head ultrasound (pre/post infusion).

group.title: High Dose Milrinone
group.description: Subjects received a bolus intravenous (IV) infusion of 50 mcg/kg/min of milrinone lactate over 1 hour followed by a continuous IV infusion of 0.5 mcg/kg/min milrinone lactate over 24 hours.

group.title: Low Dose Milrinone
group.description: Subjects received a bolus intravenous (IV) infusion of 20 mcg/kg/min of milrinone lactate over 1 hour followed by a continuous IV infusion of 0.2 mcg/kg/min milrinone lactate over 24 hours.

certain_agreements.pi_employee: All Principal Investigators ARE employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: There is NOT an agreement between Principal Investigators and the Sponsor (or its agents) that restricts the PI's rights to discuss or publish trial results after the trial is completed.

clinical_results.limitations_and_caveats: Study enrollment was terminated early resulting in a small number of evaluable subjects for analysis.
